message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A low FEV1/FVC ratio and low FEV1 suggest obstructive lung disease such as asthma. Fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is increased in patients with asthma. DLCO is decreased in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methacholine is a bronchoconstrictor and would cause a decrease in FEV1, while albuterol is a bronchodilator and would cause an increase in FEV1 in patients with asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The FEV1/FVC ratio less than 0.7 indicates obstruction of airflow, suggesting that the other pulmonary function tests will also show obstruction. Therefore, albuterol is not expected to improve FEV1. Methacholine will cause bronchoconstriction and decrease FEV1, so option B can be ruled out. DLCO measures the ability of gas to move from the lungs into the blood, and it is not directly related to obstruction, so option A is also incorrect. Fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is a marker of airway inflammation, which is often present in asthma, but does not directly indicate airflow obstruction. Therefore, option D is the most likely answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and FEV1 % predicted suggest moderate obstruction in asthma. Option (A) is incorrect because DLCO is usually normal in asthma. Option (B) is incorrect because methacholine induces bronchoconstriction and will decrease the FEV1, which is already decreased in this patient. Option (C) is incorrect because albuterol is a bronchodilator and should increase the FEV1. Option (D) is correct because nitric oxide is produced by the airway epithelium and increased fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is a marker of airway inflammation in asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low FEV1/FVC ratio and low FEV1 indicate obstructive lung disease, which is consistent with asthma. Asthma is associated with an increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide due to airway inflammation. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect as asthma often results in an increased DLCO. Option (B) is incorrect as methacholine would likely induce bronchoconstriction in an individual with asthma, leading to a decrease in FEV1. Option (C) is incorrect as albuterol is a bronchodilator that is expected to increase FEV1 in individuals with asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The asthmatic patient will have decreased FEV1 and decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. DLCO is not likely to be affected. Methacholine will cause bronchoconstriction, so there will not be an increase in FEV1 with methacholine. Albuterol is a short-acting beta agonist and bronchodilator, so it will increase FEV1. Fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is a measure of airway inflammation and is increased in asthmatic patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A ratio of FEV1/FVC less than 0.75 supports the diagnosis of airflow limitation consistent with asthma. A decreased DLCO suggests interstitial lung disease or pulmonary hypertension, not asthma. An increase in FEV1 with methacholine indicates hyperreactive airways and not related to asthma severity. A decrease in FEV1 with albuterol indicates poorly controlled asthma. An increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide indicates airway inflammation, which is associated with asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A low ratio of FEV1/FVC and a low FEV1 suggest obstructive lung disease, which is consistent with asthma. An increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is a characteristic finding in asthma, as it reflects airway inflammation. Options A and C are not expected findings in asthma, and option B would indicate a positive response to a bronchoconstrictor, which is not expected in this patient with asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In asthma, there is usually an increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide due to airway inflammation. DLCO is often decreased in obstructive lung disease but is not directly related to asthma. Methacholine will cause bronchoconstriction and decrease FEV1, while albuterol is a bronchodilator and will increase FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low FEV1 indicates obstructive lung disease, which suggests a decrease in the DLCO (A) and an increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide (D). Option B is unlikely since methacholine is a bronchoconstrictor and would decrease FEV1, and option C is unlikely since albuterol is a bronchodilator and would increase FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In persistent moderate asthma, a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and a decreased FEV1 are expected findings in the pulmonary function test. DLCO is not typically affected in asthma. Methacholine and albuterol would respectively cause a decrease and increase in FEV1, which is the opposite of what is expected, so they are not the correct answer options. An increase in fractional exhalation of nitric oxide is a noninvasive measure of airway inflammation and can be used to monitor and manage asthma.
